conversation.content: [formally] The international tribunal requested we restore your communication lines before the trial proceedings begin next week. [pause] I'll need access to the main junction box in your east wing, and I'll be working here for the next few hours.

So they send a common laborer to wire my prison. [bitter] Twenty years ago, I had thousands of men like you building entire communication networks across this nation, and now you come here to give me a single telephone line.
[firmly] I'm just here to do a job, nothing more. [clearing throat] The sooner you show me where the junction box is, the sooner I can leave and you can make whatever calls they're allowing you.
[melancholic] Do you know what I used these lines for before? [sighs] I spoke to presidents, to generals who commanded armies, to business titans who moved billions with a single word from me.
[quietly] I know what you used them for.

[defensive] You know nothing! The Western media feeds you lies about mass graves and torture chambers, but they never mention the hospitals I built, the literacy programs, the fact that we had the lowest infant mortality rate in the region under my leadership.

[angry] My brother-in-law disappeared after protesting your grain requisitions in '09. [very quietly] His family still doesn't know where his body is buried, so don't lecture me about your achievements while children went hungry to build your palaces.

[dismissive] Sacrifices had to be made for progress. [pause] Your brother-in-law chose the wrong side of history, and history is written by those with the strength to shape it, not by telephone repairmen.

[controlled] History's being rewritten right now, isn't it? [sarcastically] You're about to go from 'Supreme Leader for Life' to 'Defendant Number One' in front of the whole world, all broadcast through these very lines I'm installing.

[very quietly] They can try me, execute me if they wish, but my legacy will outlive their tribunals. [sighs] Monuments fall, but ideas persist, and there are still millions who remember when this country stood for something more than being another Western puppet state.
[frustrated] Your legacy is mass graves and starving villages! [exhales] But I'm not here to argue politics with a dead man walking, just point me to the junction box.

[melancholic] Down the hall, third door on the left, though I doubt you'll find what you're looking for. [quietly] The rats have been at the wiring for years now, just like they've been at everything else in this crumbling palace.

[professionally] I've dealt with worse conditions in war zones, which ironically, most of them exist because of men like you who thought they could reshape the world through fear and violence. [pause] The wiring will work when I'm done.

[bitter] Fear and violence? [laughs] Your democratic heroes drop bombs from drones on wedding parties and call it spreading freedom, but when I maintained order in my own borders, suddenly I'm the monster.

[firmly] The difference is accountability, something you're about to learn about firsthand when you're sitting in that defendant's chair. [quietly] Your phones will work perfectly for your lawyer calls, for what good they'll do you.

Tell me, lineman, when you're splicing those wires together, do you ever think about how many last words have traveled through copper lines like these? [melancholic] How many final goodbyes, how many pleas for mercy that went unheard?

[coldly] I think about the families who never got to say goodbye because of men like you. [sighs] But today I'm just thinking about doing my job and getting out of here before the stench of this place follows me home.

[resigned] The junction box is actually behind a portrait of my father in the hallway. [very quietly] He was a tyrant too, they say, though he only killed his enemies, not his friends like I learned to do.

[level] I'll find it and get the work done within the hour, then you can call whoever still takes your calls. [pause] The guards told me you're allowed three international calls per week now, supervised of course.

[melancholic] Three calls to a world that's already forgotten me except as a cautionary tale. [exhales] Fix your wires, lineman, and leave me to practice my defense for judges who've already decided my fate.

scenario: A telephone lineman is forced to repair communication lines at the palace of a deposed tyrant who is under house arrest awaiting his war crimes trial.
